Keywords: navbar, top nav, header, main nav, navigation bar
Description: Top-level navigation bar with logo, links, and CTA. Present on all public pages.
Do: Include logo (links to home), 4-6 primary links, CTA button (Sign Up/Get Started), mobile hamburger. Use sticky/fixed position with backdrop blur.
Don't: Don't use more than 7 nav items. Don't hide CTA on desktop. Don't use dropdown-only navigation without visible links.
Code Example Good:
Logo
links
Get Started
Code Example Bad: LogoLink1Link2

Keywords: nav cta, signup button, get started, nav action
Description: Navigation must include a prominent CTA button (Sign Up, Get Started, Try Free) that stands out from regular nav links.
Do: Use contrasting color for CTA button. Make it the rightmost element. Maintain on scroll (sticky nav). Use action-oriented text.
Don't: Don't use same style as nav links for CTA. Don't hide CTA behind hamburger on tablet. Don't use generic text like 'Click Here'.
Code Example Good: Get Started Free
Code Example Bad: Sign up

Keywords: mobile menu, hamburger, responsive nav, mobile navigation
Description: Collapsible menu for mobile viewports. Triggered by hamburger icon, reveals full navigation.
Do: Use accessible hamburger button (aria-label, aria-expanded). Animate open/close. Include all nav items + CTA. Close on outside click and Escape key.
Don't: Don't use hamburger on desktop (>1024px). Don't forget to trap focus inside open menu. Don't leave menu open on route change.
Code Example Good: nav items
Code Example Bad: ‚ò∞

Keywords: sticky nav, fixed header, scroll nav, floating nav
Description: Navbar stays visible during scroll. Use floating style (top-4 left-4 right-4) with backdrop blur for modern look.
Do: Add padding-top to body/main content to prevent overlap. Use backdrop-blur-md + semi-transparent bg. Add shadow on scroll. Use z-50.
Don't: Don't use top-0 left-0 right-0 (use top-4 left-4 right-4 for floating). Don't forget content offset. Don't make navbar too tall (max 64-72px).
Code Example Good: <nav class="fixed top-4 left-4 right-4 z-50 bg-white/80 backdrop-blur-md rounded-2xl shadow-lg">...</nav><main class="pt-24">content</main>
Code Example Bad: <nav class="fixed top-0 left-0 right-0 bg-white">...</nav><main>content hidden behind nav</main>

Keywords: breadcrumb, path, hierarchy, trail, navigation path
Description: Show user's current location in site hierarchy. Essential for e-commerce, blogs, admin panels with nested pages.
Do: Use semantic nav with aria-label='Breadcrumb'. Separate with '/' or '>'. Last item is current page (not a link). Use structured data (BreadcrumbList schema).
Don't: Don't use breadcrumbs on landing/home page. Don't make breadcrumb text too long (truncate middle items). Don't use for flat site structures.
Code Example Good:
1. Home
  2. /
  3. Blog
  4. /
  5. Post Title
Code Example Bad: Home > Blog > Post Title

Keywords: sidebar, side nav, app nav, dashboard nav, vertical nav
Description: Vertical navigation for dashboards and app interfaces. Contains categorized links, user menu, and collapse toggle.
Do: Group links by category with section headers. Show active state clearly. Make collapsible on mobile (overlay). Include user avatar + menu at bottom. Add keyboard navigation.
Don't: Don't use sidebar for marketing pages. Don't show more than 8-10 items without grouping. Don't auto-collapse on desktop without user preference.
Code Example Good:
Logo
Main
Dashboard
User menu
Code Example Bad: Link1Link2

Keywords: footer, bottom, site footer, page footer
Description: Site-wide footer with organized links, social media, legal info, and copyright. Present on all public pages.
Do: Organize links in 3-5 columns (Product, Company, Resources, Legal, Social). Include copyright with current year. Add social media icons. Include newsletter signup optional.
Don't: Don't duplicate all nav items (curate footer links). Don't use tiny font sizes (min 14px). Don't forget legal links (Privacy Policy, Terms of Service). Don't use emojis for social icons.
Code Example Good:
Product

Features
...
¬© 2024 Company. All rights reserved.
Code Example Bad: <footer class="bg-gray-100 p-4 text-center text-xs">¬© Company</footer> <!-- Too minimal, no links, no structure -->

Keywords: legal, privacy, terms, cookie, gdpr, compliance
Description: Every public-facing page must include legal links in the footer: Privacy Policy, Terms of Service, Cookie Policy (if applicable).
Do: Place legal links in footer bottom section. Link to actual legal pages. Include 'Privacy Policy' and 'Terms of Service' at minimum.
Don't: Don't hide legal links. Don't link to placeholder/empty pages. Don't forget Cookie Policy for EU compliance.
Code Example Good: Privacy PolicyTerms of ServiceCookie Policy
Code Example Bad: <!-- No legal links anywhere in footer -->

Keywords: internal links, cross links, page connections, navigation flow
Description: Pages must link to related pages logically. Sign In ‚Üî Sign Up, Landing ‚Üí Pricing, Dashboard ‚Üí Settings, etc.
Do: Every auth page links to its counterpart. Landing CTA ‚Üí Sign Up. Dashboard nav ‚Üí all app sections. Blog posts ‚Üí related posts. Pricing ‚Üí Sign Up per plan.
Don't: Don't create orphan pages (no incoming links). Don't link to external sites for core navigation. Don't use generic anchor text ('click here').
Code Example Good: Don't have an account? Sign up
Code Example Bad: <!-- Sign In page with no link to Sign Up --> <form>...login fields...</form> <!-- Dead end -->

Keywords: bottom nav, mobile tab bar, app navigation, tab navigation
Description: Fixed bottom navigation bar for mobile app-like experiences. Shows 3-5 primary actions with icons.
Do: Use exactly 3-5 items max. Include icons + labels (not icon-only). Highlight active tab. Use safe-area padding for notch devices. Fixed to bottom with z-index.
Don't: Don't use bottom nav on desktop. Don't use more than 5 items. Don't use bottom nav AND hamburger menu simultaneously.
Code Example Good: Home...

Keywords: mega menu, dropdown menu, large nav, expanded nav
Description: Expanded dropdown showing categorized links, featured content, or product previews. For sites with many pages.
Do: Open on hover (desktop) or click (mobile). Group items with headings. Include images/icons for visual interest. Close on outside click. Add subtle entrance animation.
Don't: Don't use mega menu for sites with <10 pages. Don't make it cover full viewport height. Don't auto-open on page load. Don't forget keyboard navigation.
Code Example Good:
Products

Item 1
Code Example Bad: LinkLink

Keywords: tabs, tab bar, section tabs, content tabs
Description: Horizontal tabs for switching between content sections within a page. Common in settings, dashboards, profiles.
Do: Use accessible tabs (role=tablist/tab/tabpanel, aria-selected). Show active tab clearly. Use border-bottom or bg color for active state. Support keyboard arrows.
Don't: Don't use too many tabs (max 6-7). Don't nest tabs within tabs. Don't use tabs for sequential steps (use stepper instead).
Code Example Bad: Tab1Tab2

Keywords: pagination, page numbers, next previous, paging
Description: Navigate between pages of content (blog posts, search results, product lists). Show current page and total.
Do: Show current page highlighted. Include Previous/Next buttons. Show first/last page numbers. Use aria labels. Disable Previous on first page, Next on last.
Don't: Don't show all page numbers for 100+ pages (use ellipsis). Don't use infinite scroll without option to paginate. Don't forget to preserve scroll position.
Code Example Good: <nav aria-label="Pagination" class="flex gap-2"><button disabled class="px-3 py-1 text-gray-400">Prev</button><button class="px-3 py-1 bg-blue-600 text-white rounded">1</button><button class="px-3 py-1">2</button><button class="px-3 py-1">Next</button></nav>
Code Example Bad: 123...99

Keywords: skip link, skip navigation, a11y nav, accessibility skip
Description: Hidden link that becomes visible on focus, allows keyboard users to skip directly to main content.
Do: Place as first focusable element in DOM. Make visible on focus with transition. Link to #main-content id. Use clear text 'Skip to main content'.
Don't: Don't remove skip link for visual design reasons. Don't make it permanently visible (only on focus). Don't forget the matching id on main content.
Code Example Good:
Skip to main content
...
Code Example Bad: <!-- No skip link at all -->

Keywords: auth links, signin signup link, login register link, auth navigation
Description: Sign In and Sign Up pages must always link to each other. Users frequently need to switch between them.
Do: Sign In: 'Don't have an account? Sign up' below form. Sign Up: 'Already have an account? Sign in' below form. Sign In: 'Forgot password?' link near password field.
Don't: Don't hide cross-links. Don't use ambiguous text. Don't forget Forgot Password on Sign In page.
Code Example Good: Don't have an account? Sign up for free
Code Example Bad: <!-- Sign In page with no mention of Sign Up --> <!-- Dead end for new users -->

Keywords: sitemap, hierarchy, structure, information architecture, site map
Description: Logical organization of pages into a clear hierarchy. Important pages within 3 clicks of homepage.
Do: Landing ‚Üí Features/Pricing/About/Blog/Contact. Auth: Sign In/Sign Up/Forgot Password. App: Dashboard ‚Üí Settings/Profile. Blog: List ‚Üí Post ‚Üí Related.
Don't: Don't create pages deeper than 3 levels. Don't have orphan pages. Don't duplicate content across multiple URLs.
Code Example Good: / (Landing) ‚Üí /pricing ‚Üí /signup ‚Üí /dashboard ‚Üí /settings | /blog ‚Üí /blog/post-slug | /about, /contact
Code Example Bad: / ‚Üí /category/subcategory/sub-sub/item/detail ‚Üí 5+ levels deep

Keywords: url, slug, path, routing, url pattern
Description: Clean, descriptive URLs that reflect page hierarchy. Use lowercase, hyphens, no special characters.
Do: Use descriptive slugs (/blog/how-to-build-api). Keep URLs short (<75 chars). Use consistent patterns (/blog/:slug, /products/:id). Match URL to breadcrumbs.
Don't: Don't use query params for primary content (?page=about). Don't use underscores or camelCase. Don't include file extensions (.html). Don't use IDs only (/post/12345).
Code Example Good: /pricing, /blog/getting-started-with-nextjs, /products/wireless-headphones, /dashboard/settings
Code Example Bad: /?p=123, /Blog/MyPost, /products/item.html, /dashboard/Settings_Page

Keywords: active state, current page, selected nav, active link
Description: Currently active page/section must be visually distinguished in navigation. Users must know where they are.
Do: Use color change + font weight + border/background for active state. Apply to both sidebar and top nav. Update on route change. Use aria-current='page'.
Don't: Don't rely only on color change (add border or background too). Don't forget to update active state on client-side navigation. Don't highlight parent when child is active (highlight both).
Code Example Good: Dashboard
Code Example Bad: Dashboard

Keywords: nav search, search bar, global search, search input
Description: Global search functionality accessible from navigation. Allows users to find content across the entire site/app.
Do: Place search in top nav (right side or center). Use Cmd/Ctrl+K shortcut. Show search icon on mobile. Include search suggestions/autocomplete. Use proper input with type='search'.
Don't: Don't hide search behind multiple clicks. Don't use search without results page. Don't make search too small on desktop (<200px).
Code Example Bad: <input type="text" placeholder="Search"> <!-- No icon, no shortcut hint, wrong type -->

Keywords: user menu, avatar dropdown, account menu, profile dropdown
Description: Dropdown menu triggered by user avatar/name in navigation. Contains profile, settings, and logout links.
Do: Show user avatar + name. Include Profile, Settings, Billing (if applicable), and Logout. Use dividers between groups. Close on outside click. Add keyboard navigation.
Don't: Don't hide logout deep in settings. Don't show user menu to unauthenticated users. Don't forget hover/focus states on menu items.
Code Example Good:
ProfileSettings
Log out
Code Example Bad: Profile
